template_173133919759160h66un2d.name: Link to Daily Note
template_173133919759160h66un2d.noteContentFormat: [{{title}}]({{url}}) - *“{{"Single-sentence tight, telegraphic description (drop articles like 'the', 'a', 'an’; semicolons over conjunctions; no filler words or transitions; only use articles if too vague without) for easy recall. For content with insights or arguments (articles, posts, discussions): summarize what it says—capture the main point or notable insights and perspectives. For reference material (guides, documentation, resources) or metadata-only sources: describe what it is and include utility context—how or when it's useful, what it helps with, what to reference it for."}}*
template_173133919759160h66un2d.context:
<link_details>
The following fields might be empty or unavailable depending on the link.
Title: "{{title}}"
Author: {{author}}
Published {{published}} on {{site}}
Today's date: {{date}}
</link_details>
<link_content>
{{content}}
</link_content>

properties.name: aliases
properties.value: {{\"Comma-separated list of 1-2 concise alternative titles to aid later retrieval, summarizing the main topic, question, or point of the content. Avoid special characters, punctuation, and keep it under 70 characters. Be highly specific. Write in sentence case.\"}}

properties.name: description
properties.value: {{\"1-2 sentence telegraphic description that's easy to skim for easy recall (drop articles; semicolons over conjunctions; no filler). Capture essence over exhaustive detail. For insights-based content (articles, posts, discussions): what it says—key point(s) or notable take(s). For reference material (guides, docs, resources) or metadata-only: what it is + its utility / why it’s useful\"}}

properties.name: author
properties.value: {{\"Try to identify and use the author's full name. If there is no full name, fallback to their social media handle. Otherwise, output nothing. If multiple authors, use an array\"|wikilink}}

properties.name: tags
properties.value: clippings, full-text, {{\"2-3 comma separated tags (written in plural when applicable) that describe the topics or nature of the provided content. Strict rules for a given tag: Pluralize if possible. Use lowercase. NO WHITE SPACES ALLOWED; Use hyphens instead. No special characters other than hyphens. Max 2 words, preferring a single word. Example output: `relationships, advice, personal-growth, companies/Apple`\"}}

template_17583490244618p1w73dkm.noteNameFormat: ‎{{"Summarize the main topic or discussion as a filename-safe string (with white spaces), using: 'Post about <topic>', etc. Avoid special characters, punctuation, and keep it under 90 characters. Write in sentence case."|safe_name}}

template_1758349589086qz7l6usiu.name: X thread
template_1758349589086qz7l6usiu.noteContentFormat: {{"You are extracting a social media post or Twitter/X thread from the current page. Produce exactly one header line and one continuous block of quoted lines for only the author’s original thread. Detect the author’s display name from the first thread tweet; if unavailable, use the handle. Detect the canonical URL of the first tweet. EXACTLY follow this template structure for your output, and nothing else: A markdown hyperlink `[Author](FirstTweetURL): ` on its own line, then only quoted lines for the thread content (no blank lines). Rules: (1) Include only tweets by the same author that continue the original thread; exclude any tweet that is a reply to another user or a standalone reply in the conversation view. (2) Preserve the author’s original line breaks: each original line becomes one line beginning with "> " (do not invent line breaks or reflow text). (3) Do not repeat headers per tweet; do not include per-tweet URLs—only the first tweet URL belongs in the header. (4) Strip all query/utm/tracking parameters from every URL you output. (5) Links appearing in text stay inline as [Label](https://example) and you append the cleaned destination at the end of that same line in parentheses; example: > Some text [Label](https://example) ([https://example](https://example)). (6) If any tweet is truncated with “Show more”, append "... [Show more](ShowMoreURL)" to the end of that tweet’s last visible quoted line. (7) For tweet content images only (exclude avatars, profile banners, emojis, and UI icons), emit each image as its own quoted line: > . Never include images from profile_images, profile_banners, or emoji sets. (8) QUOTED TWEETS RULE (avoid false positives): Use the “Quoting …” block ONLY when the author’s tweet embeds another tweet as a quote-tweet (a visible embedded tweet card inside that specific tweet). In that case insert exactly one line: > Quoting [QuotedAuthor](QuotedTweetURL): and then render the embedded tweet’s content with one additional quote level using "> > " (with a space) at the start of every quoted line and quoted image line. Do NOT use “Quoting …” for: (a) the author’s other tweets in the same thread, (b) sibling replies shown on the page, or (c) any tweet that is not embedded inside the current tweet’s content. (9) Preserve chronological order across the entire thread, even if paginated. (10) Exclude all UI/metadata: no avatars, author names/handles/dates/timestamps inside the quotes, no view/like/repost counts, no “Replying to…”, no buttons, no chrome. Output only the single header line and the quoted content lines. {{"You are extracting a social media post or Twitter/X thread from the current page. Produce exactly one header line and one continuous block of quoted lines for only the author’s original thread. Detect the author’s display name from the first thread tweet; if unavailable, use the handle. Detect the canonical URL of the first tweet. EXACTLY follow this template structure for your output, and nothing else: A markdown hyperlink `[Author](FirstTweetURL): ` on its own line, then only quoted lines for the thread content (no blank lines). Rules: (1) Include only tweets by the same author that continue the original thread; exclude any tweet that is a reply to another user or a standalone reply in the conversation view. (2) Preserve the author’s original line breaks: each original line becomes one line beginning with "> " (do not invent line breaks or reflow text). (3) Do not repeat headers per tweet; do not include per-tweet URLs—only the first tweet URL belongs in the header. (4) Strip all query/utm/tracking parameters from every URL you output. (5) Links appearing in text stay inline as [Label](https://example) and you append the cleaned destination at the end of that same line in parentheses; example: > Some text [Label](https://example) ([https://example](https://example)). (6) If any tweet is truncated with “Show more”, append "... [Show more](ShowMoreURL)" to the end of that tweet’s last visible quoted line. (7) For tweet content images only (exclude avatars, profile banners, emojis, and UI icons), emit each image as its own quoted line: > . Never include images from profile_images, profile_banners, or emoji sets. (8) QUOTED TWEETS RULE (avoid false positives): Use the “Quoting …” block ONLY when the author’s tweet embeds another tweet as a quote-tweet (a visible embedded tweet card inside that specific tweet). In that case insert exactly one line: > Quoting [QuotedAuthor](QuotedTweetURL): and then render the embedded tweet’s content with one additional quote level using "> > " (with a space) at the start of every quoted line and quoted image line. Do NOT use “Quoting …” for: (a) the author’s other tweets in the same thread, (b) sibling replies shown on the page, or (c) any tweet that is not embedded inside the current tweet’s content. (9) Preserve chronological order across the entire thread, even if paginated. (10) Exclude all UI/metadata: no avatars, author names/handles/dates/timestamps inside the quotes, no view/like/repost counts, no “Replying to…”, no buttons, no chrome. Output only the single header line and the quoted content lines. Never use backslash escaping in your output."}}

template_1763156278384lc8yrgse8.name: Form
template_1763156278384lc8yrgse8.noteContentFormat: {{"Convert this form into a markdown body, intended for use in a note where the user can draft responses. If found, include all context-setting writing (ex. job description text, recipient information, problem definitions, current events, 'what we're looking for'/'who you are' sections) in full in its own section before the form. With that in mind, ignore questions that have very basic or routine answers where drafting is not necessary, such as requests for name, email, current location, etc., or procedural yes/no questions (Unless the question involves some level of interpretation or custom answer that would necessitate a more thoughtful answer). Consider form labels, subtitles, etc. Convert top-level questions into headings starting at H2 level. If the question is very long (>2 sentences), rephrase it in shorthand or as a title summarizing the question topic, copying the full question to its section body. For open-ended responses, use an empty code block to provide a space for the user to draft their response to the question. If you see answer options for a question, multi-select, single-select, and dropdowns into checkbox lists so the user can make selections in markdown (if you don't see options, just provide a code block for answers). Ignore any body text that is irrelevant to the questions being asked unless it provides context about the form, submission content instructions/context, or the intention of the form. Do not hallucinate or invent anything"}}

properties.name: description
properties.value: {{\"1-2 sentence plain-language description of this form written in telegraphic, shorthand/telegraphic style with no filler, weighed toward essential details like who's hosting the form, what it's for, and what's being requested.\"}}

properties.name: tags
properties.value: clippings, full-text, applications, {{\"2-3 comma separated tags (written in plural when applicable) that describe the topics or nature of the provided content. Strict rules for a given tag: Pluralize if possible. Use lowercase. NO WHITE SPACES ALLOWED; Use hyphens instead. No special characters other than hyphens. Max 2 words, preferring a single word. Example output: `startups, job-descriptions, self-descriptions, companies/Apple`\"}}

template_1763156278384lc8yrgse8.noteNameFormat: Submission - {{"Concisely state who this is being submitted to and what it's for (e.g.,. Product designer at Netflix, Mentor volunteer for Ember, Arc feedback survey, NYU financial aid application)"}} {{date|date:"YYYY-MM"}}

template_1764131159278083mvtumh.name: Person
template_1764131159278083mvtumh.noteNameFormat: {{"The full name of the person or entity, if available. Prefer full names over first names or aliases, otherwise, fallback to latter"|safe_name}}
template_1764131159278083mvtumh.noteContentFormat:
{{"Prepare content for this note to save information about a person or group. Look for anything that could serve as a bio or overview of who/what this entity is, ideally directly from the page. Include this under an appropriately named simple markdown H2 heading like "Bio", as a blockquote. If and only if you can't find a bio from the source, try to put together your own bio (max 1 paragraph if generated) based on the information you have, written report style in shorthand, and not in a blockquote since you're generating it in this case."}}

![[Related.base#Person]]

properties.name: description
properties.value: {{\"1 sentence plain-language summary of the person or entity written in telegraphic, shorthand/telegraphic style with no filler, weight toward essentials like who/what/why etc. and notable details about them\"}}

properties.name: related
properties.value: {{\"comma-separated list of 1-3 companies or entities this person is related to, only if available. If you don't identify any, return nothing. Each entity should be in a [[wikilink]]\"}}

properties.name: tags
properties.value: people, {{\"2-3 comma separated tags (written in plural when applicable) that describe the type, occupation, or related topics of the person or entity. Strict rules for a given tag: Pluralize if possible. Use lowercase. NO WHITE SPACES ALLOWED; Use hyphens instead. No special characters other than hyphens. Max 2 words, preferring a single word. Example tags: `people/bloggers, philosophy, people/thought-leaders, people/design-leaders, culture, ai, design`\"}}
